    21	class BlockSpaceManagerV2(BlockSpaceManager):
    22	    """BlockSpaceManager which manages the allocation of KV cache.
    23	
    24	    It owns responsibility for allocation, swapping, allocating memory for
    25	    autoregressively-generated tokens, and other advanced features such as
    26	    prefix caching, forking/copy-on-write, and sliding-window memory allocation.
    27	
    28	    The current implementation is partial; in particular prefix caching and
    29	    sliding-window are not feature complete. This class implements the design
    30	    described in https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm/pull/3492.
    31	
    32	    Lookahead slots
    33	        The block manager has the notion of a "lookahead slot". These are slots
    34	        in the KV cache that are allocated for a sequence. Unlike the other
    35	        allocated slots, the content of these slots is undefined -- the worker
    36	        may use the memory allocations in any way.
    37	
    38	        In practice, a worker could use these lookahead slots to run multiple
    39	        forward passes for a single scheduler invocation. Each successive
    40	        forward pass would write KV activations to the corresponding lookahead
    41	        slot. This allows low inter-token latency use-cases, where the overhead
    42	        of continuous batching scheduling is amortized over >1 generated tokens.
    43	
    44	        Speculative decoding uses lookahead slots to store KV activations of
    45	        proposal tokens.
    46	
    47	        See https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm/pull/3250 for more information
    48	        on lookahead scheduling.
    49	
    50	    Args:
    51	        block_size (int): The size of each memory block.
    52	        num_gpu_blocks (int): The number of memory blocks allocated on GPU.
    53	        num_cpu_blocks (int): The number of memory blocks allocated on CPU.
    54	        watermark (float, optional): The threshold used for memory swapping.
    55	            Defaults to 0.01.
    56	        sliding_window (Optional[int], optional): The size of the sliding
    57	            window. Defaults to None.
    58	        enable_caching (bool, optional): Flag indicating whether caching is
    59	            enabled. Defaults to False.
    60	    """
    61	
    62	    def __init__(
    63	        self,
    64	        block_size: int,
    65	        num_gpu_blocks: int,
    66	        num_cpu_blocks: int,
    67	        watermark: float = 0.01,
    68	        sliding_window: Optional[int] = None,
    69	        enable_caching: bool = False,

    71	        self.block_size = block_size
    72	        self.num_total_gpu_blocks = num_gpu_blocks
    73	        self.num_total_cpu_blocks = num_cpu_blocks
    74	
    75	        self.sliding_window = sliding_window
    76	        # max_block_sliding_window is the max number of blocks that need to be
    77	        # allocated

    81	            num_blocks = sliding_window // block_size + 1

    83	            # and so the sequence stretches one more block at the beginning

    85	            # we may need 2 blocks when the second block only holds 1 token.
    86	            self.max_block_sliding_window = num_blocks + 1

   110	    def can_allocate(self, seq_group: SequenceGroup) -> AllocStatus:

   201	        new allocation (either via CoW or new block). We can append slots if the
   202	        number of touched blocks is less than the number of free blocks.
   203	
   204	        "Lookahead slots" are slots that are allocated in addition to the slots
   205	        for known tokens. The contents of the lookahead slots are not defined.
   206	        This is used by speculative decoding when speculating future tokens.
   207	        """

   213	            num_touched_blocks += (

    21	class BlockSpaceManagerV2(BlockSpaceManager):
    22	    """BlockSpaceManager which manages the allocation of KV cache.
    23	
    24	    It owns responsibility for allocation, swapping, allocating memory for
    25	    autoregressively-generated tokens, and other advanced features such as
    26	    prefix caching, forking/copy-on-write, and sliding-window memory allocation.
    27	
    28	    The current implementation is partial; in particular prefix caching and
    29	    sliding-window are not feature complete. This class implements the design
    30	    described in https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm/pull/3492.
    31	
    32	    Lookahead slots
    33	        The block manager has the notion of a "lookahead slot". These are slots
    34	        in the KV cache that are allocated for a sequence. Unlike the other
    35	        allocated slots, the content of these slots is undefined -- the worker
    36	        may use the memory allocations in any way.
    37	
    38	        In practice, a worker could use these lookahead slots to run multiple
    39	        forward passes for a single scheduler invocation. Each successive
    40	        forward pass would write KV activations to the corresponding lookahead
    41	        slot. This allows low inter-token latency use-cases, where the overhead
    42	        of continuous batching scheduling is amortized over >1 generated tokens.
    43	
    44	        Speculative decoding uses lookahead slots to store KV activations of
    45	        proposal tokens.
    46	
    47	        See https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm/pull/3250 for more information
    48	        on lookahead scheduling.
    49	
    50	    Args:
    51	        block_size (int): The size of each memory block.
    52	        num_gpu_blocks (int): The number of memory blocks allocated on GPU.
    53	        num_cpu_blocks (int): The number of memory blocks allocated on CPU.
    54	        watermark (float, optional): The threshold used for memory swapping.
    55	            Defaults to 0.01.
    56	        sliding_window (Optional[int], optional): The size of the sliding
    57	            window. Defaults to None.
    58	        enable_caching (bool, optional): Flag indicating whether caching is
    59	            enabled. Defaults to False.
    60	    """

   195	    def can_append_slots(self, seq_group: SequenceGroup,
   196	                         num_lookahead_slots: int) -> bool:
   197	        """Determine if there is enough space in the GPU KV cache to continue
   198	        generation of the specified sequence group.
   199	
   200	        We use a worst-case heuristic: assume each touched block will require a
   201	        new allocation (either via CoW or new block). We can append slots if the
   202	        number of touched blocks is less than the number of free blocks.
   203	
   204	        "Lookahead slots" are slots that are allocated in addition to the slots
   205	        for known tokens. The contents of the lookahead slots are not defined.
   206	        This is used by speculative decoding when speculating future tokens.
   207	        """

   209	        num_touched_blocks = 0
   210	        for seq in seq_group.get_seqs(status=SequenceStatus.RUNNING):
   211	            block_table = self.block_tables[seq.seq_id]
   212	
   213	            num_touched_blocks += (
   214	                block_table.get_num_blocks_touched_by_append_slots(
   215	                    token_ids=block_table.get_unseen_token_ids(
   216	                        seq.get_token_ids()),
   217	                    num_lookahead_slots=num_lookahead_slots,
   218	                ))
   219	
   220	        num_free_gpu_blocks = self.block_allocator.get_num_free_blocks(
   221	            Device.GPU)
   222	        return num_touched_blocks <= num_free_gpu_blocks

    54	            # The "* extra_factor" is a buffer to allow more block objects
    55	            # than physical blocks

    57	                                         num_blocks * extra_factor)

    60	            # which means that there is most likely a need to share

   156	        """Creates a new sequence of blocks that shares the same underlying

   174	            refcount = self._refcounter.incr(block.block_id)

   184	            prev_block = forked_blocks[-1]

   291	
   292	        Args:

   299	                swapping in/out the given blocks and num_lookahead_slots.
   300	        """

   302	        # seqs, also we compare the empty slots in the mutable blocks with
   303	        # lookahead slots to get the number of unique new block that are

   149	        self._free_block_id(block)
   150	
   151	        # Release the block object
   152	        if not keep_block_object:
   153	            self._block_pool.free_block(block)
   154	
   155	    def fork(self, last_block: Block) -> List[Block]:
   156	        """Creates a new sequence of blocks that shares the same underlying
   157	        memory as the original sequence.
   158	
   159	        Args:
   160	            last_block (Block): The last block in the original sequence.
   161	
   162	        Returns:
   163	            List[Block]: The new sequence of blocks that shares the same memory
   164	                as the original sequence.
   165	        """
   166	        source_blocks = get_all_blocks_recursively(last_block)
   167	
   168	        forked_blocks: List[Block] = []
   169	        prev_block = None
   170	        for block in source_blocks:
   171	
   172	            # Increment refcount for each block.
   173	            assert block.block_id is not None
   174	            refcount = self._refcounter.incr(block.block_id)
   175	            assert refcount != 1, "can't fork free'd block"
   176	
   177	            forked_block = self._block_pool.init_block(
   178	                prev_block=prev_block,
   179	                token_ids=block.token_ids,
   180	                block_size=self._block_size,
   181	                physical_block_id=block.block_id)
   182	
   183	            forked_blocks.append(forked_block)
   184	            prev_block = forked_blocks[-1]
   185	
   186	        return forked_blocks
   187	
   188	    def get_num_free_blocks(self) -> int:
   189	        return len(self._free_block_indices)
   190	
   191	    def get_num_total_blocks(self) -> int:
   192	        return len(self._all_block_indices)
   193	
   194	    def get_physical_block_id(self, absolute_id: int) -> int:
   195	        """Returns the zero-offset block id on certain block allocator
   196	        given the absolute block id.
   197	
   198	        Args:
   199	            absolute_id (int): The absolute block id for the block 
   200	            in whole allocator.
   201	
   202	        Returns:
   203	            int: The zero-offset block id on certain device.
   204	        """
   205	        return sorted(self._all_block_indices).index(absolute_id)
   206	
   207	    @property
   208	    def refcounter(self):
   209	        return self._refcounter
   210	
   211	    @property
   212	    def all_block_ids(self) -> FrozenSet[int]:
   213	        return self._all_block_indices
   214	
   215	    def cow_block_if_not_appendable(self, block: Block) -> BlockId:
   216	        """Performs a copy-on-write operation on the given block if it is not
   217	        appendable.
   218	
   219	        Args:
   220	            block (Block): The block to check for copy-on-write.
   221	
   222	        Returns:
   223	            BlockId: The block index of the new block if a copy-on-write 
   224	                operation was performed, or the original block index if
   225	                no copy-on-write was necessary.
   226	        """
   227	        src_block_id = block.block_id
   228	        assert src_block_id is not None
   229	
   230	        if self._cow_tracker.is_appendable(block):
   231	            return src_block_id
   232	
   233	        self._free_block_id(block)
   234	        trg_block_id = self._allocate_block_id()
   235	
   236	        self._cow_tracker.record_cow(src_block_id, trg_block_id)
   237	
   238	        return trg_block_id
   239	
   240	    def clear_copy_on_writes(self) -> List[Tuple[BlockId, BlockId]]:
   241	        """Returns the copy-on-write source->destination mapping and clears it.
   242	
   243	        Returns:
   244	            List[Tuple[BlockId, BlockId]]: A list mapping source
   245	                block indices to destination block indices.
   246	        """
   247	        return self._cow_tracker.clear_cows()
   248	
   249	    def mark_blocks_as_accessed(self, block_ids: List[int],
   250	                                now: float) -> None:
   251	        """Mark blocks as accessed, used in prefix caching.
   252	
   253	        Since the naive allocator does not implement prefix caching, we do
   254	        nothing.
   255	        """
   256	        pass
   257	
   258	    def mark_blocks_as_computed(self, block_ids: List[int]) -> None:
   259	        """Mark blocks as computed, used in prefix caching.
   260	
   261	        Since the naive allocator does not implement prefix caching, we do
   262	        nothing.
   263	        """
   264	        pass
   265	
   266	    def get_computed_block_ids(self, prev_computed_block_ids: List[int],
   267	                               block_ids: List[int],
   268	                               skip_last_block_id: bool) -> List[int]:
   269	        """No prefix caching here => return empty list
   270	        """
   271	        return []
   272	
   273	    def get_common_computed_block_ids(
   274	            self, computed_seq_block_ids: List[List[int]]) -> List[int]:
   275	        """Determine blocks that can be skipped in prefill.
   276	
   277	        Since the naive allocator does not support prefix caching, always return
   278	        an empty list.
   279	        """
   280	        return []
   281	
   282	    def promote_to_immutable_block(self, block: Block) -> BlockId:
   283	        raise NotImplementedError("There is no promotion for naive blocks")
   284	
   285	    def get_num_blocks_touched(self,
   286	                               blocks: List[Block],
   287	                               num_lookahead_slots: int = 0) -> int:
   288	        """Determine the number of blocks that will be touched by
   289	        swapping in/out the given blocks from certain sequence
   290	        group with the provided num_lookahead_slots.
   291	
   292	        Args:
   293	            blocks (List[Block]): The potential blocks to swap.
   294	            num_lookahead_slots (int): number of lookahead slots (0 for swap 
   295	                out).
   296	        
   297	        Returns:
   298	            int: the number of blocks that will be touched by
   299	                swapping in/out the given blocks and num_lookahead_slots.
   300	        """
   301	        # NOTE: for naive block, we use set to eliminate common blocks among
   302	        # seqs, also we compare the empty slots in the mutable blocks with
   303	        # lookahead slots to get the number of unique new block that are
   304	        # needed.
   305	        old_block_set = set()
   306	        new_block_count = 0
   307	        # TODO(cade): make sure the logic is correct and clean it up.
   308	        for block in blocks:
   309	            if not block.is_full and num_lookahead_slots != 0:
   310	                new_block_count += 1
   311	                if num_lookahead_slots > block.num_empty_slots:
   312	                    new_block_count += cdiv(
   313	                        num_lookahead_slots - block.num_empty_slots,
   314	                        self._block_size)
   315	            else:
   316	                old_block_set.add(block.block_id)
   317	        num_touched_blocks = new_block_count + len(old_block_set)
   318	        return num_touched_blocks
   319	
   320	    def swap_out(self, blocks: List[Block]) -> None:
   321	        for block in blocks:
   322	            self._free_block_id(block)
   323	
   324	    def swap_in(self, blocks: List[Block]) -> None:
   325	        for block in blocks:
   326	            # Here we allocate either immutable or mutable block and then
   327	            # extract its block_id. Note that the block object is released
   328	            # and the block_id is assigned to "block" to allow reusing the
   329	            # existing "block" object
   330	            if block.is_full:
   331	                tmp_block = self.allocate_immutable_block(
   332	                    prev_block=block.prev_block, token_ids=block.token_ids)
   333	            else:
   334	                tmp_block = self.allocate_mutable_block(
   335	                    prev_block=block.prev_block)
   336	                tmp_block.append_token_ids(block.token_ids)
   337	
   338	            block_id = tmp_block.block_id
   339	            tmp_block.block_id = None
   340	            self._block_pool.free_block(tmp_block)

     9	class BlockTable:
    10	    """A class to manage blocks for a specific sequence.
    11	
    12	    The BlockTable maps a sequence of tokens to a list of blocks, where each
    13	    block represents a contiguous memory allocation for a portion of the 
    14	    sequence. The blocks are managed by a DeviceAwareBlockAllocator, which is
    15	    responsible for allocating and freeing memory for the blocks.
    16	
    17	    Args:
    18	        block_size (int): The maximum number of tokens that can be stored in a
    19	            single block.
    20	        block_allocator (DeviceAwareBlockAllocator): The block allocator used to
    21	            manage memory for the blocks.
    22	        _blocks (Optional[List[Block]], optional): An optional list of existing
    23	            blocks to initialize the BlockTable with. If not provided, an empty
    24	            BlockTable is created.
    25	        max_block_sliding_window (Optional[int], optional): The number of
    26	            blocks to keep around for each sequance. If None, all blocks
    27	            are kept (eg., when sliding window is not used).
    28	            It should at least fit the sliding window size of the model.
    29	
    30	    Attributes:
    31	        _block_size (int): The maximum number of tokens that can be stored in a
    32	            single block.
    33	        _allocator (DeviceAwareBlockAllocator): The block allocator used to
    34	            manage memory for the blocks.
    35	        _blocks (Optional[List[Block]]): The list of blocks managed by this
    36	            BlockTable.
    37	        _num_full_slots (int): The number of tokens currently stored in the
    38	            blocks.
    39	    """
    40	
    41	    def __init__(
    42	        self,
    43	        block_size: int,
    44	        block_allocator: DeviceAwareBlockAllocator,
    45	        _blocks: Optional[List[Block]] = None,
    46	        max_block_sliding_window: Optional[int] = None,
    47	    ):
    48	        self._block_size = block_size
    49	        self._allocator = block_allocator
    50	        if _blocks is None:
    51	            _blocks = []
    52	        self._blocks: BlockList = BlockList(_blocks)
    53	
    54	        self._max_block_sliding_window = max_block_sliding_window
    55	        self._num_full_slots = self._get_num_token_ids()
    56	
    57	    @staticmethod
    58	    def get_num_required_blocks(token_ids: List[int], block_size: int) -> int:
    59	        """Calculates the minimum number of blocks required to store a given
    60	        sequence of token IDs.
    61	
    62	        This assumes worst-case scenario, where every block requires a new
    63	        allocation (e.g. ignoring prefix caching).
    64	
    65	        Args:
    66	            token_ids (List[int]): The sequence of token IDs to be stored.
    67	            block_size (int): The maximum number of tokens that can be stored in
    68	                a single block.
    69	
    70	        Returns:
    71	            int: The minimum number of blocks required to store the given
    72	                sequence of token IDs.
    73	        """
    74	        return cdiv(len(token_ids), block_size)
    75	
    76	    def allocate(self,
    77	                 token_ids: List[int],
    78	                 device: Device = Device.GPU) -> None:
    79	        """Allocates memory blocks for storing the given sequence of token IDs.
    80	
    81	        This method allocates the required number of blocks to store the given
    82	        sequence of token IDs.
    83	
    84	        Args:
    85	            token_ids (List[int]): The sequence of token IDs to be stored.
    86	            device (Device, optional): The device on which the blocks should be
    87	                allocated. Defaults to Device.GPU.
    88	        """
    89	        assert not self._is_allocated
    90	        assert token_ids
    91	        blocks = self._allocate_blocks_for_token_ids(prev_block=None,
    92	                                                     token_ids=token_ids,
    93	                                                     device=device)
    94	        self.update(blocks)
    95	        self._num_full_slots = len(token_ids)
    96	
    97	    def update(self, blocks: List[Block]) -> None:
    98	        """Resets the table to the newly provided blocks 
    99	        (with their corresponding block ids)
   100	        """
   101	        self._blocks.update(blocks)
   102	
   103	    def append_token_ids(self,
   104	                         token_ids: List[int],
   105	                         num_lookahead_slots: int = 0,
   106	                         num_computed_slots: Optional[int] = None) -> None:
   107	        """Appends a sequence of token IDs to the existing blocks in the
   108	        BlockTable.
   109	
   110	        This method appends the given sequence of token IDs to the existing
   111	        blocks in the BlockTable. If there is not enough space in the existing
   112	        blocks, new blocks are allocated using the `ensure_num_empty_slots`
   113	        method to accommodate the additional tokens.
   114	
   115	        The token IDs are divided into chunks of size `block_size` (except for
   116	        the first chunk, which may be smaller), and each chunk is appended to a
   117	        separate block.
   118	
   119	        Args:
   120	            token_ids (List[int]): The sequence of token IDs to be appended.
   121	            num_computed_slots (Optional[int]): The number of KV cache slots
   122	                that are already filled (computed).
   123	                When sliding window is enabled, this is used to compute how many
   124	                blocks to drop at the front of the sequence.
   125	                Without sliding window, None can be passed.
   126	                Without chunked prefill, it should be the same as
   127	                _num_full_slots.
   128	        """
   129	        assert self._is_allocated, "no blocks have been allocated"
   130	        assert len(self._blocks) > 0
   131	
   132	        # Drop blocks that are no longer needed due to sliding window
   133	        if self._max_block_sliding_window is not None:
   134	            null_block = self._allocator.allocate_or_get_null_block()
   135	            assert num_computed_slots is not None
   136	            end_block_idx = (num_computed_slots //
   137	                             self._block_size) - self._max_block_sliding_window
   138	            for idx in range(0, end_block_idx):
   139	                b = self._blocks[idx]
   140	                if b is not null_block:
   141	                    self._allocator.free(b)
   142	                    self._blocks[idx] = null_block
   143	
   144	        # Ensure there are enough empty slots for the new tokens plus
   145	        # lookahead slots
   146	        self.ensure_num_empty_slots(num_empty_slots=len(token_ids) +
   147	                                    num_lookahead_slots)
   148	
   149	        # Update the blocks with the new tokens
   150	        first_block_idx = self._num_full_slots // self._block_size
   151	        token_blocks = self._chunk_token_blocks_for_append(token_ids)
   152	
   153	        for i, token_block in enumerate(token_blocks):
   154	            self._blocks.append_token_ids(first_block_idx + i, token_block)
   155	
   156	        self._num_full_slots += len(token_ids)
   157	
   158	    def ensure_num_empty_slots(self, num_empty_slots: int) -> None:
   159	        """Ensures that the BlockTable has at least the specified number of
   160	        empty slots available.
   161	
   162	        This method checks if the BlockTable has enough empty slots (i.e.,
   163	        available space) to accommodate the requested number of tokens. If not,
   164	        it allocates additional blocks on the GPU to ensure that the required
   165	        number of empty slots is available.
   166	
   167	        Args:
   168	            num_empty_slots (int): The minimum number of empty slots required.
   169	        """
   170	        # Currently the block table only supports
   171	        # appending tokens to GPU blocks.
   172	        device = Device.GPU
   173	        assert self._is_allocated
   174	
   175	        if self._num_empty_slots >= num_empty_slots:
   176	            return
   177	
   178	        slots_to_allocate = num_empty_slots - self._num_empty_slots
   179	        blocks_to_allocate = cdiv(slots_to_allocate, self._block_size)
   180	
   181	        for _ in range(blocks_to_allocate):
   182	            assert len(self._blocks) > 0
   183	            self._blocks.append(
   184	                self._allocator.allocate_mutable_block(
   185	                    prev_block=self._blocks[-1], device=device))
   186	
   187	    def fork(self) -> "BlockTable":
   188	        """Creates a new BlockTable instance with a copy of the blocks from the
   189	        current instance.
   190	
   191	        This method creates a new BlockTable instance with the same block size,
   192	        block allocator, and a copy of the blocks from the current instance. The
   193	        new BlockTable has its own independent set of blocks, but shares the
   194	        same underlying memory allocation with the original BlockTable.
   195	
   196	        Returns:
   197	            BlockTable: A new BlockTable instance with a copy of the blocks from
   198	                the current instance.
   199	        """

arguments.new_str:
# Test case for marking cache hit blocks as computed right after
    # a batch of prefill sequences are scheduled.
    @staticmethod
    def test_touch_block():
        block_size = 16
        common_blocks = 4
        allocator = PrefixCachingBlockAllocator(num_blocks=8,
                                                block_size=block_size)

        common_token_ids = list(range(block_size * common_blocks))

        # Mimic the behavior of allocating the same block chain
        # (i.e., common prefix) for a batch of 3 different prefill sequences.
        first_chain = TestPrefixCachingBlockAllocator.create_immutable_chain(
            block_size=block_size,
            token_ids=common_token_ids,
            allocator=allocator,
        )
        # Record the block ids from the first allocation
        first_block_ids = [block.block_id for block in first_chain]

        # Allocate two more chains sharing the same prefix
        for _ in range(2):
            _ = TestPrefixCachingBlockAllocator.create_immutable_chain(
                block_size=block_size,
                token_ids=common_token_ids,
                allocator=allocator,
            )

        # The blocks from the first chain should be touched (tracked) but
        # not computed yet.
        for bid in first_block_ids:
            assert allocator._block_tracker[bid].active
            assert allocator._block_tracker[bid].computed is False

# Test case for marking cache hit blocks as computed right after
    # a batch of prefill sequences are scheduled.
    @staticmethod
    def test_touch_block():
        block_size = 16
        common_blocks = 4
        allocator = PrefixCachingBlockAllocator(num_blocks=8,
                                                block_size=block_size)

        common_token_ids = list(range(block_size * common_blocks))

        # Mimic the behavior of allocating the same block chain
        # (i.e., common prefix) for a batch of 3 different prefill sequences.
        first_chain = TestPrefixCachingBlockAllocator.create_immutable_chain(
            block_size=block_size,
            token_ids=common_token_ids,
            allocator=allocator,
        )
        # Record the block ids from the first allocation
        first_block_ids = [block.block_id for block in first_chain]

        # Allocate two more chains sharing the same prefix
        for _ in range(2):
            _ = TestPrefixCachingBlockAllocator.create_immutable_chain(
                block_size=block_size,
                token_ids=common_token_ids,
                allocator=allocator,
            )

        # The blocks from the first chain should be touched (tracked) but
        # not computed yet.
        for bid in first_block_ids:
            assert allocator._block_tracker[bid].active
            assert allocator._block_tracker[bid].computed is False

import time
from vllm.core.block.prefix_caching_block import PrefixCachingBlockAllocator

# Benchmark prefix caching block allocation with common prefixes
block_size = 16
num_blocks = 256
num_sequences = 8
common_prefix_blocks = 4

# Create allocator
allocator = PrefixCachingBlockAllocator(num_blocks=num_blocks, block_size=block_size)

# Common token IDs for shared prefix
common_token_ids = list(range(block_size * common_prefix_blocks))

# Time the allocation and marking operation
start = time.time()

# Allocate blocks for multiple sequences with common prefixes
for seq_idx in range(num_sequences):
    prev_block = None
    for block_idx in range(common_prefix_blocks):
        start_idx = block_idx * block_size
        end_idx = start_idx + block_size
        token_ids = common_token_ids[start_idx:end_idx]

        block = allocator.allocate_immutable_block(
            prev_block=prev_block,
            token_ids=token_ids
        )
        prev_block = block

# Mark blocks as computed (optimized path should make this cheap/no-op)
try:
    allocator.mark_blocks_as_computed([])
except NotImplementedError:
    pass

duration = time.time() - start
print(f"Duration: {duration:.6f} seconds")
print(f"Cache hit rate: {allocator.get_prefix_cache_hit_rate():.3f}")

import time
import sys
from pathlib import Path

# Ensure repo root is on sys.path
ROOT = Path(__file__).resolve().parents[1]
sys.path.insert(0, str(ROOT))

from vllm.core.block.prefix_caching_block import PrefixCachingBlockAllocator

# Benchmark prefix caching block allocation with common prefixes
block_size = 16
num_blocks = 256
num_sequences = 8
common_prefix_blocks = 4

allocator = PrefixCachingBlockAllocator(num_blocks=num_blocks, block_size=block_size)

# Common token IDs for shared prefix
common_token_ids = list(range(block_size * common_prefix_blocks))

# Time the allocation and marking operation
start = time.time()

# Allocate blocks for multiple sequences with common prefixes
for seq_idx in range(num_sequences):
    prev_block = None
    for block_idx in range(common_prefix_blocks):
        start_idx = block_idx * block_size
        end_idx = start_idx + block_size
        token_ids = common_token_ids[start_idx:end_idx]

        block = allocator.allocate_immutable_block(
            prev_block=prev_block,
            token_ids=token_ids
        )
        prev_block = block

# Mark blocks as computed (optimized operation path should be fast/no-op)
try:
    allocator.mark_blocks_as_computed([])
except NotImplementedError:
    pass

# Report timing and cache rate
duration = time.time() - start
print(f"Duration: {duration:.6f} seconds")
print(f"Cache hit rate: {allocator.get_prefix_cache_hit_rate():.3f}")

   112	        """Checks if the block is shared or not. If shared, then it cannot
   113	        be appended and needs to be duplicated via copy-on-write
   114	        """
   115	        block_id = block.block_id
   116	        if block_id is None:

   118

   129	                is copied

   131	        assert src_block_id is not None
   132	        assert trg_block_id is not None
   133	        self._copy_on_writes.append((src_block_id, trg_block_id))

   145	                block indices to destination block indices for the
   146	                current copy-on-write operations.

   221	class BlockList:
   222	    """This class is an optimization to allow fast-access to physical 
   223	    block ids. It maintains a block id list that is updated with the 
   224	    block list and this avoids the need to reconstruct the block id 
   225	    list on every iteration of the block manager
   226	    """
   227

   229	        self._blocks: List[Block] = []

   235	        assert block_id is not None

   239	                         new_block_id: Optional[BlockId]) -> None:
   240	        assert new_block_id is not None
   241	        self._block_ids[block_index] = new_block_id
   242	
   243	    def update(self, blocks: List[Block]):
   244	        self._blocks = blocks
   245	
   246	        # Cache block ids for fast query
   247	        self._block_ids = []
   248	        for block in self._blocks:

   286	@dataclass
   287	class CacheMetricData:
   288	    """A utility dataclass to maintain cache metric.
   289	    To avoid overflow, we maintain the hit rate in block granularity, so that
   290	    we can maintain a single hit rate for n_completed_block x block_size,
   291	    and calculate the real time hit rate by the following:
   292	    BS = The number of queries per block.
   293	    nB = The number of completed blocks.
   294	    HR = hit rate of (nB x BS) queries.
   295	    Q = current number of queries (< BS).
   296	    H = current number of hits (< BS).
   297	    hit rate = ((HR x nB) + (H / Q) x (Q / BS)) / (nB + Q / BS)
   298	    """
   299	    num_completed_blocks: int = 0
   300	    completed_block_cache_hit_rate: float = 0.0
   301	    num_incompleted_block_queries: int = 0
   302	    num_incompleted_block_hit: int = 0
   303	    block_size: int = 1000
   304	
   305	    def query(self, hit: bool):
   306	        self.num_incompleted_block_queries += 1
   307	        self.num_incompleted_block_hit += 1 if hit else 0
   308	
   309	        # When a block is completed, update the cache hit rate
   310	        # and reset the incomplete numbers.
   311	        if self.num_incompleted_block_queries == self.block_size:
   312	            hit_rate = (self.num_incompleted_block_hit /
   313	                        self.num_incompleted_block_queries)
   314	            self.completed_block_cache_hit_rate = (
   315	                self.completed_block_cache_hit_rate * self.num_completed_blocks
   316	                + hit_rate) / (self.num_completed_blocks + 1)
   317	            self.num_incompleted_block_queries = 0

arguments.message:
Implemented performance optimizations for prefix caching and added fast paths:

Changes made:
- vllm/core/block/prefix_caching_block.py
  - Implemented mark_blocks_as_computed: fast no-op for empty input and bulk mark of trackers as computed for provided block IDs.
  - Added early return in mark_blocks_as_accessed when block_ids is empty.
- vllm/core/block_manager_v2.py
  - Implemented mark_blocks_as_computed to mark full (non-last) blocks of scheduled sequences as computed when caching is enabled.
- tests/core/block/test_prefix_caching_block.py
  - Added new test test_touch_block to validate touched (tracked) but not computed behavior for newly created blocks across shared prefixes.

Benchmarking:
- Created .bench_scratch/test_opt.py and .bench_scratch/test_opt2.py to time allocation flows with shared prefixes. Verified runtime and cache hit rate.
  - Ran: python3 .bench_scratch/test_opt.py
  - Output sample: Duration ~0.0001s, Cache hit rate ~0.875 (demonstrates fast path and cache hits).

Commit and patch:
- Staged and committed changes.
- Exported patch to model_patch.diff.

Next steps:
- Optionally run broader test suites if available to ensure correctness across the codebase.
- Integrate with the full scheduler to observe end-to-end improvements in scenarios using BlockManagerV2.

Artifacts:
- Patch: /home/raven/coding-mess/kernel-corp/OmniPerf-Bench/perf-agents-bench/.work/worktrees/vllm_core/vllm_core-0011/model_patch.diff
